questions.question: I hate the idea ……………….. old.
questions.description: The noun idea is followed by a preposition + ing form.

questions.question: The thought ……………… never bothered him.
questions.description: The noun thought is followed by a preposition + ing form.

questions.question: She is very clever ……………….. problems.
questions.description: The adjective clever is followed by the preposition at + ing form.

questions.question: Have you got anything ………………. flies?
questions.description: After something and anything, we use for + ing form to explain the purpose of an object.

questions.question: You can’t eat meat without …………….. an animal.
questions.description: After a preposition, we use an ing form.

questions.question: You must always check the oil before ……………… the vehicle.
questions.description: After a preposition, we use an ing form.

questions.question: I am not used to ………………. in a major city.
questions.description: When to is a preposition, it is followed by an ing form. A common expression in which this happens is ‘be used to’.

questions.question: Do you object to ……………. on weekends?
questions.description: In the expression object to, ‘to’ is a preposition. We use ing forms after prepositions.

questions.question: Be careful when you talk to him. He is inclined to ……………… his temper.
questions.description: The verb inclined is followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: We are waiting for the guests …………….
questions.description: The verb wait is followed by for + object + infinitive.

questions.question: We regret …………… passengers that the flight to Amsterdam has been cancelled.
questions.description: Regret is followed by an infinitive in announcements of bad news.

questions.question: I regret ……………… out of college. It was a big blunder.
questions.description: Regret is followed by an ing form to refer back to the past.
